intro: Monochaetum humboldtianum var. chardonii, commonly known as the Humboldt's spikegrass, is a rare and distinctive plant native to the coastal regions of South America. It belongs to the grass family (Poaceae) and is characterized by its slender, tufted growth habit with long, narrow leaves. The plant produces dense spikes of small, pale green to yellowish flowers, which bloom in late summer. It thrives in sandy or gravelly soils and is often found in coastal dunes or rocky outcrops. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a vulnerable species in its native range.
